This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r}

days <- c('Mon','Tue','Wed','Thur','Fri','Sat','Sun')
temp <- c(28,30.5,32,31.2,29.3,27.9,26.4)
snowed <- c('T','T','F','F','T','T','F')

help("data.frame")

RPI_Weather_Week <- data.frame(days,temp,snowed)
RPI_Weather_Week
```

```{r}
head(RPI_Weather_Week) #Default head shows first 6 rows
str(RPI_Weather_Week) 
summary(RPI_Weather_Week)
```

```{r}
RPI_Weather_Week[1,] #Showing row 1

RPI_Weather_Week[,1] #Showing column 1

RPI_Weather_Week[,'snowed'] #Showing the values of column snowed
RPI_Weather_Week[,'days'] #Showing the values of column days
RPI_Weather_Week[,'temp']
RPI_Weather_Week[1:5,c('days','temp')] #Showing the first 5 entries in columns days and temp

RPI_Weather_Week$temp #takes temp column

subset(RPI_Weather_Week, subset=snowed==TRUE) #Not good use filter

sorted.snowed <- order(RPI_Weather_Week['snowed'])
sorted.snowed

RPI_Weather_Week[sorted.snowed,]

dec.snow <- order(-RPI_Weather_Week$temp)
dec.snow
```

```{r}
epi_df <- read.csv("/Users/paullee/Downloads/EPI_data.csv", header=TRUE)
epi2010_df <- read.csv("/Users/paullee/Downloads/2010EPI_data.csv", header=TRUE)

```

```{r}
summary(epi_df)
fivenum(epi_df$EPI,na.rm=TRUE)
stem(epi_df$EPI)

#hist(AirPassengers, 
#     main="Histogram for Air Passengers", 
#     xlab="Passengers", 
#     border="blue", 
#     col="green",
#     xlim=c(100,700),
#     las=1, 
#     breaks=5)

hist(epi_df$EPI, main="Histogram for EPI")

#To run the dist line and rug you have to run with the histogram 
hist(epi_df$EPI, main="Histogram of EPI", seq(30.,95.,1.0), prob=TRUE)
lines(density(epi_df$EPI,na.rm=TRUE,bw=1))
rug(epi_df$EPI)

#Cumulative density function
plot(ecdf(epi_df$EPI), main="ECDF of EPI", do.points=FALSE, verticals=TRUE)

#QQ Chart
par(pty="s")
qqnorm(epi_df$EPI, main="QQ Plot of EPI")
qqline(epi_df$EPI)

x <- seq(30,95,1)
qqplot(qt(ppoints(250),df=5),x,main="QQ Plot for Generating Distribution",xlab="Q-Q plot for tdsn")
qqline(x)

#Exercise 1 - Primary Variables for epi_df is Daly, Water_H

#fivenum for var Daly
fivenum(epi_df$DALY,na.rm=TRUE)
#fivenum for var Water_H
fivenum(epi_df$WATER_H, na.rm=TRUE)
#Stems for daly an water_h
stem(epi_df$DALY)
stem(epi_df$WATER_H)

hist(epi_df$EPI, main="Histogram of DALY", seq(30.,95.,1.0), prob=TRUE)
lines(density(epi_df$DALY,na.rm=TRUE,bw=1))
rug(epi_df$DALY)

hist(epi_df$EPI, main="Histogram of Water_H", seq(30.,95.,1.0), prob=TRUE)
lines(density(epi_df$WATER_H,na.rm=TRUE,bw=1))
rug(epi_df$WATER_H)

#boxplot for daly and epi
boxplot(epi_df$DALY,epi_df$EPI, main="Daly and EPI Comparison")

#qqplot for daly and epi
qqplot(epi_df$EPI,epi_df$DALY, main="Daly and EPI QQ Plot")
```
